MV'AN WILLIAMS : Did you say. Miners or Mineowners? MR. CHURCHILLt The Mining Association,How there" are two quite distinct points which are habitually confused. The first is this. Assuming that there will continue to be, as there has been since 1921, a National Agreement dealing with certain aspects of the wage question and District Agreements dealing with others, what subjects are to be dealt with in each? In particular, is the minimum percentage to continue to find a place in the National Agreement, as the men claim, or is it to be transferred to the District Agreements, as the owners claim? That is what I may call one . uestion.. That is the first question^ The second question is this. Is there tov.-bo any National Agreement at all or is the industry in future to bo regulated purely by District Agreements without any National Wage Negotiating bodies? That is the second, the alternative, uestion. Now up to the meeting between yourselves and the men on the 19th August the issue was Nosl, the issue ims the first of those questions. On the 19th August, owing to your declaration, the issue became No.2; it became the second of those questions. That is the point with which we are concerned at the present moment and that is the only ;;oint with which we are conoexned at the present moment and it is very important that that point should not be obscured by being mixed up with the first and' more complicated point, let ma state what, in my judgment, is the issue across the table at the momenta It is, is there to be any National Agreement at all, or is the industry in future to be regulated purely by Diet riot Agreements without any National Wage negotiating body? Now that is the only point to which I want to ash you to address yourselves this afternoon, as todetailsit is perfectly clear that there must be District Agreements, It is perfectly clear that this matter can never be settled in all its details of wages and hours by a conference in London-; it has got to be settled in the districts, but the extent to which the District Agreements are related to a National structure, the extent to whioh national machinery on both sides is to be preserved, that is the issue before us at the present time. Now I should like, if you will allow me, to make some quotations from your declarations in the past, Mr.Willi ms. When this question first arose you argued before the Royal Commission that any form of National Agreement was wrong and that the industry ought to revert to the pre-war system of regulation by Distriot Agreements, Well, the Royal Commission did not accept that view. I am not one of those who consider that the Royal Commission Report is a sort of bible , from which everything that is quoted is necessarily absolutely authoritative, because I think that would be putting its credentials too high, but still it is the fact that y ou argued in that sense and the Royal Commission saici on page 236 "We consider it essential that there should be, as there always have been hitherto, considerably variations in the rates of wages in the several districts, but we are strongly of the opinion that National Wage Agreements should continue." Now in the face of this declaration the Mining Association withdrew from the position which they had taken up in giving evidence before the Commission and at your meeting with the men on the 51st March, you will permit me to quote your words, you said :-"I say quite frankly that we are making a sacrifice of our conviction, which is not a thing to coast about or to take any credit for, from that point of view But we are not going to stand on the ground whi h we have taken up in the past in regard to this matter, and we are prepared, in order that we may get on with the real problem that faces us, to sit down with you an to carry on negotiations on a national basis, upon general principles, and upon such things as are "f general application to "the industry, and to enter into a national agreement with you on the same lines." later on in the same meeting you said, Mr. Evan Williams:-"If we had any desire or intention at all either to break up, or even to weaken the influence of the Miners1 federation, we should not have been doing what we have done today - sitting down with you to consider this uestion nationally and telling you what you probably dia not expect to hear, that, notwithstanding what we said to the Commission, we are prepared to negotiate a national agreement with you between the Miners' Pe eration and the Mining Association.On the 13th April you met again ano reaffirmed yourposition in the following words:-"We have said that we are prepared to discussand arrange with you a National Agreement. We areprepared to do that, and to determine ,the principlesupon which the ascertainments of wages should be madein the different districts, and that all that isnecessary to enable those ascertainments to be made should be determined on a national basis as betweenyou and us on lines similar to those which have beenin operation in the past, with the one qualificationwhich we have put to you and which is I think you must agree, inevitable, that a national minimum isno longer possible."That would probably mean "a national uniform minimum is nolonger possible". Finally on the 22nd April, the last meetingStoppage .'hat took place before the / you went so far as tout before the men the draft of a National Agreement and in handing this draft to Mr.Herbert Smith you said"Mr. Smith and gentlemen, as we indicated to you at our last meeting, that we were prepared to discuss with you the terms of a national agreement, Howe proceeded at the earliest opportunity to got into shape proposals in a definite form, insofar as its main lines are Concerned, at any rate, for the agreement which, in our view, should he made as between the Miners1 Federation and the Mining Association, We had this submit ted in draft to our distriots last week, and yesterday we were in a position to send to you, in a form approved by the districts, the proposals which v/e make in regard to it I do not know whether the better procedure would not be to go through . tha agroetaent in detail and to diuouss i isV' \clauses as we prooeed, so that we may have your view upon them and so that you may have our explanations insofar as they are necessary." It is now necessary to turn to the proceeding^ which took place after the stoppage had begun. At this meeting on the 14th May when the Eight Hours Bill was und discussion you gave no indication to us of any change in your attitude as defined in the quotations I have read out. On the contrary you said "As to the basis of negotiations we are quite prepared to meet the Miners1 Federation at any time on a perfectly open situation".' ' : ' if; MSThat is a very good phrase Ba perfectly open situation'.It is what I have in my mind and what I am asking you to do today. Comprised in these proposals was thesuggestion that a National Board should 1 frame a nationalAssociationWage and Hours Agreement". To t his your / s en t in a long elaborate and argumentative written reply;but it contained no specific comment or demurrer on this point. Then we come to the 1st May and you defined the position, in an interview with the Minister of Labour, in the following words"I want to make this quite clear., It may not be very palatable, but I think it only right that I should tell you exactly how we feel in this-.matter. The Mining Association, a such, as you know, has no powers to deal with wages vuestions except at the direct request of I the District Associations, and all that it is necessary for the districts to do, or even one district to do to prevent any negotiations being carried on centrally is to say that they withdraw their authority to the Mining Association to deal with the matter for then. I know, will weigh with you perhaps more than any other argument that I am going to use.how let me just touch on a point which requires a little blunt speakingothe most important and specific of these quotations which I have read from your speeches , were before the Stoppagebegan, and of course it stands to reason that in the hope of averting a great misfortune like that everything is offered, even things that one does not think desirable are offered, If they can possibly be. the means of staving off the catastrophe But when foreighteen weeks the country has been thrown into its present ccn-dition and when you gentlemen, as I know well, have been suffer'-ing in a very formidable manner leases perhaps of 600,000 oeven 700,000 a week, in keeping the pits from falling to pieces and being flooded, when peace has not hoesecured, I am quite prepared to say that a new situation arises.
